page.title: 01Forest, farm and water
page.content: The metamorphic mica schist rock of this area was carved out by Glaciers about 12000 years ago. This created flat hill tops, steep sided hills and a deep loch. The receding sea level has left raised beach deposits - used for farming, sand and gravel, roads, settlement and a caravan site. Arable and livestock (cattle) farming continue up to a height of 150 metres. Surrounding the farm and up to 300 metres there are forestry plantations, mainly of jitka spruce. Above 300 metres the land is given over to sheep farming; here the landscape is wind swept and marshy - an inhospitable environment. As the hills are "low" they are only used by the outdoor centres in the area for recreation. Loch Long provides an ever changing scene of wind and waves.
